course.title: Disease and Public Health in Modern East Asian History
course.description: Disease and epidemics are important agents of historical change. With the formation of the modern state, the control of infectious disease became both a means and a goal in the exercise of power. Simultaneously, individual experiences of disease and the place of the body in society also were transformed. This course examines responses to infectious disease in modern China, Japan, and Korea, focusing the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. We will explore the history of disease and public health using methodological approaches ranging from biology to anthropology and iconology, with a focus on cholera, plague, tuberculosis, and AIDS.
